header.title: All schools to get support on teaching LGBT lessons after angry parent protests
header.postText: Every school in Britain will be given support to be able to teach children about same-sex relationships in the wake of anti-LGBT protests by some parents.', 'Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said headteachers should be ‘able to teach about Britain as it is today’ and will be delivering support to schools ahead of the September 2020 mandatory introduction of same-sex relationship education.', 'In some of his first comments on the matter since being appointed to his new role, Mr Williamson added that the government has ‘set out quite clearly’ the law and said there is no place for protests outside any school.', 'He said: ‘Firstly, we shouldn’t be seeing protests outside any schools.', '‘We want to make sure all pupils, parents and teachers are able to go to those schools freely without any form of intimidation.', '‘We will be there supporting and backing every single school – that’s what we have been doing.', '‘The purpose of it is we wanted to make sure every single school is able to teach about Britain as it is today – but also have the flexibility to ensure that it has an understanding of the communities which it operates in.’', 'Before the summer holidays, anti-LGBT protests were held by parents outside Anderton Park and Parkfield Community Primary schools in Birmingham, with a separate demonstration outside the gates of Nottingham’s Fernwood Primary.', 'Demonstrators claimed that teaching about LGBT relationships was ‘over-emphasising a gay ethos’ and that the teachings were not ‘age appropriate’.', 'Counter-protesters also congregated outside the schools, with LGBT campaigners slamming the ‘homophobic’ demonstrations.', 'Mr Williamson said he had no plans to visit the headteacher of Birmingham’s Anderton Park Primary School, Sarah Hewitt-Clarkson, who said she was subjected to weeks of abuse after weaving information about the Equality Act into her school’s wider curriculum.', 'In June, the headteacher – who claims she received death threats – called for Mr Williamson’s predecessor, Damian Hinds, to visit and have a discussion about the current policy on relationships and LGBT education in schools.', 'Speaking at the time, she warned of the angry demonstrations spreading without the government giving more support to schools affected.', 'She said: ‘The importance of this goes beyond Anderton Park, it goes beyond protests on my pavements – it’s a British law issue.’', 'The DfE said it has been working ‘very closely’ with heads on the issue and Mr Hinds did meet union officials and officers from Birmingham City Council.', 'Parkfield school’s ‘No Outsiders’ equality education programme, which taught about diversity and difference in modern society, was suspended last term in the wake of parent protests.', 'But in July, the school announced that a modified version of it would return in the new term.', 'In June, the Department for Education published guidance encouraging schools to adopt the new curriculum on relationships education from this September.
